awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Correlated States in Twisted Hetero-bilayer Transition Metal Dichalcogenides
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract: 
In conventional materials, electrons travel in the periodic arrays of atoms without "talking" (interacting) to each other. When two monolayers of atomically thin materials, also knowns as two-dimensional (2D) materials, are stacked together with a well-controlled twist angle between these two layers, they form a new periodic structure with interesting properties. In this collaborative project, the PIs investigate these 2D materials to gain knowledge that could enable transformative technology innovations such as high-temperature superconductivity, quantum electronics and optoelectronics. This project integrates an education component to train students and build a strong workforce for quantum science and technologies. Under-represented groups are particularly encouraged and included in the education programs.

Technical Abstract: 
Correlated states such as Mott insulators and Wigner crystals remain intriguing subjects of physics. More recently, twisted hetero-bilayer transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) have emerged as a new platform with even more enhanced correlation strength, and their strong spin-orbit coupling and presence of bandgaps provide new avenues to explore spin-related physics and optoelectronics in correlated states. In this collaborative proposal, the PIs explore the moiré superlattices formed by twisted hetero-bilayer TMDs. The research plan includes two main thrusts. Thrust I is to characterize the interaction strength of the correlated states and study its relationship with moiré structure parameters and external controls to manipulate the correlated states. Thrust II is to explore new correlated states arising from interactions with other electronic phases, such as the interplay of correlated states with Landau levels, the effect of strong correlation on valley physics and excitonic physics of the moiré superlattice, and other types of new states that could possibly arise in this strongly interacting system. The collaborative project trains graduate and undergraduate students are trained for future placement in quantum science and technologies. The project also creates research modules for outreach to K-12 students and actively involves under-represented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, the PI has studied the electronic properties in moire superlattice structures formed by a class of two-dimensional semiconductor materials known as transitional metal dichalcogenides (TMD). The moire superlattice is constructed by stacking two layers of TMD materials at a small angle close to their crystalline axis. The different lattice periodicities in the two layers will result in an interference pattern that has a much longer periodicity than individual atomic lattices. Such long wavelength periodic lattice strongly modifies the electronic properties of these semiconducting materials. Electrons can strongly interact with each other, leading to new types of correlated electronic states.

In our project, we have applied a combination of electrical and optical characterization techniques to study the properties of these newly formed electronic states in the TMD moire systems. Using a sharp metal tip to deliver a microwave electrical signal to interact with the 2D materials, conductivity of the sample can be extracted and used to indicate the formation of insulating states. Using optical spectroscopy, properties of excitons, the bound pairs of electrons and holes when optically exciting a semiconductor, can be detected. The information obtained from these complementary techniques has been combined to provide a comprehensive understanding of the correlated electronic states.

Specifically, we have studied the following TMD moire systems.

In moire superlattice of monolayer (1L) WS2 / 1L WSe2, a high power optical excitation can create a high density of optical excitons. As the density of optical excitons approaches one per moire unit cell, an excitonic Mott insulator state, an analog of the electronic Mott insulator, will appear due to the dipolar interactions among excitons.

In 1L WS2 / bilayer (2L) WSe2 structure, we find that by applying an electric field to tune the carrier occupation in the two layers of WSe2, we obtain an excitonic insulating state that consists of equilibrium excitons with holes in one WSe2 layer and electrons in the other WSe2 layer. In this case, the holes and electrons couple strongly via Coulomb interaction.

In 1L WSe2 / 1L WS2 / 1L WSe2 moire superlattice, we have observed a quadrupolar exciton which is a hybridization of the two interlayer dipolar exciton species in the symmetric trilayer structure. An interlayer exciton (electron-hole pair) can form with the hole in the top WSe2 layer and the electron in the middle WS2 layer. Similarly, another interlayer exciton can also form between the middle WS2 and the bottom WSe2 layers. These interlayer dipolar excitons can then hybridize to form a quadrupolar exciton with a shared electron in the middle WS2 layer that couples to hole in both the top and bottom WSe2 layers.

In 1L WS2 / trilayer (3L) WSe2 moire superlattice, we have observed the hybridization of two species of interlayer excitons between the first and third WSe2 layers. The holes of the two interlayer excitons reside in the first WSe2 layer but at different locations within the moire unit cell. The electrons reside in the third WSe2. Due to different symmetries of the two hole locations, these two interlayer excitons normally would not hybridize. But now with the help of the third layer, their hybridization is enabled and can be further tuned by a vertical electric field.

These results obtained from this project provide new insights on the correlated electronic states in the TMD moire superlattices. They demonstrate that, by adding multiple layers, new types of correlated electronic states across the layers can emerge due to the strong interactions in this system. This further allows new ways of manipulating these correlated states via an electric field. We have further developed new measurement capabilities to probe the correlated states, which can be readily applied to other 2D material devices to characterize their electrical and optical properties.

This project has supported the training and education of graduate and undergraduate students. Two graduate students have worked on this project. One has graduated with a PhD degree, and the other is on track to graduate in a few months. Three undergraduate students have worked on this project. One has graduated and entered tech industry. The other two are applying for graduate programs. The results from this project have been used in presentations to freshman undergraduate students for research introduction and to high school science teachers during the Summer Teacher Academy hosted by the Physics and Astronomy Department at UCR. We have further hosted lab tours for high school teachers and undergraduate students from local colleges.
